subject: Management
title: Lewin's Three Stages
description: A micro-lesson that makes Lewin's Three Stages usable.

hook.text: Kurt Lewin used an ice cube metaphor in the 1940s. It's still one of the best change models today.

buildup.text: Three stages: unfreeze the current state, change to the new state, refreeze to lock it in.

discovery.text: Unfreezing means creating dissatisfaction with the status quo. Without it, nobody moves.

twist.text: Most leaders rush to the change phase. But without proper unfreezing, the change slides right off.

climax.text: Spend time unfreezing: show why the current way can't continue. Then change. Then refreeze with new norms.

punchline.text: Unfreeze, change, refreeze. Simple to say, hard to do.

quiz.question: What is the first stage of Lewin's change model?
options: Unfreezing the current state by creating dissatisfaction with it
Immediately implementing the new changes as quickly as possible
Refreezing new behaviors into permanent organizational norms
